text:
Fort Washington Park: A westward view across the southern portion of same from a point above Riverside Drive (foreground), at Haven Ave. and West 177th Street. The Jersey highlands in the background will shortly be connected with Manhattan by the new George Washington Bridge and which will o'ershadow the portion of the Park appearing on the extreme right.

May 27, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

Fort Washington Park: A well in a rocky ridge (seen in No. 2) at a point about on a line with West 178th Street.

May 27, 1927.
Views 1 and 2.

P. L. Sperr.

Fort Washington Park: A well in a rocky ridge (seen in No. 2) at a point about on a line with West 178th Street.

May 27, 1927.
Views 1 and 2.

P. L. Sperr.

Fort Washington Park: Southward from the pedestrian bridge crossing the New York Central Railroad tracks, at a point about on a line with West 178th Street, The area to the right forms what was formerly known as Jeffrey's Hook, a promontory upon which a light house sets. It boasted, at one time, a one gun "lumette" or moon shaped battery built in 1775, overlooking the spot where ships were sunk in an effort to obstruct the British fleet during the American Revolution.
View 2, of this set is similar though several years later.

1923.
View 2: May 27, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

Fort Washington Park: Southward from the pedestrian bridge crossing the New York Central Railroad tracks, at a point about on a line with West 178th Street, The area to the right forms what was formerly known as Jeffrey's Hook, a promontory upon which a light house sets. It boasted, at one time, a one gun "lumette" or moon shaped battery built in 1775, overlooking the spot where ships were sunk in an effort to obstruct the British fleet during the American Revolution.
View 2, of this set is similar though several years later.

1923.
View 2: May 27, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

Riverside Drive, south from a point on a line with W. 173rd Street, as viewed from the raised ramp leading to 177th Street at Haven Avenue.

At the right is Fort Washington Park. The raised apartment structures at the left are No's 138 and 150, and 126 to 84 Haven Avenue. These face on the west side of this thoroughfare and have a rear frontage overlooking the Drive.

Later views of same will show their exposed steel parts enclosed in concrete.

May 27, 1927

P. L. Sperr

Riverside Drive, west side, north from West 177th Street, showing a portion of Fort Washington Park. A similar photograph at a later date will show the George Washington Bridge overshadowing the mid-ground.

May 27, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

text:
Fort Washington Park: A view showing Manhattan's only lighthouse nestling beneath the George Washington Bridge. This sets on a promontory formerly known as Jeffery's Hook. A moon shaped battery, built here in 1775, overlooked the spot where ships were sunk to obstruct the British fleet during the American Revolution.

October 21, 1938

George D. Chinn
title: Manhattan: Fort Washington Park - [Lighthouse.]

Lighthouse, Ft. Washington Park. Aug. 21, 1939
P.L. Sperr, photographer
title: Manhattan: Fort Washington Park - [Lighthouse.]

P. L. Sperr
August 21, 1939
